moves.8. Be6+ Kc6 9. Bxg4 Bg7: This seems to be the most logical continuation, considering 2...g6.
moves.10. d3: White hastens to develop his dsb but with the Q still on d8, this seems to just lose a pawn and enable Black's Q to assume a dangerous position in the heart of White's position.
moves.10... exd3 11. Bf3+ Kb6 12. Nc3 Bxc3+ 13: This pawn is a thorn in White's side and prevents Rb1+
moves.14. Be3+ c5: ?  Not because it's a blunder but because it was played without even noticing the possibility of White's reply.
moves.15. Bxc5+: !? If 15...Kxc5, 16. Bxb7 followed by Bxa8... but, as Freddy has explained elsewhere, White can't afford to swap off his bishops so perhaps Black shouldn't have worried about it.
moves.15... Ka6 16. Be2+: White is hunting down Black's king.  Can he escape?
moves.16... Ka5 17. Ne6 Qc8 18. Bb4+ Kb6 19. N: ?!  White might do better to repeat with 19. Bc5+.  Black would probably have to accept the draw.
moves.19... Nc6 20. Nxc6: ?  White swaps off one of his attacking pieces and now Black takes over.
moves.24... Qd4+ 25. Kh1 Rf2: Black seeks to force more exchanges and force home his c-pawn.
moves.27... Rd8 28. Kh2 Rd4: forking two pawns and skewering one of them to a bishop but White can break the skewer with check.
moves.29. Re1 Qxe1: The sac is only temporary as the Queen is soon replaced when the c-pawn promotes.
moves.30. Bxe1 Kc7: There's no need to give up the rook by allowing it to be pinned against the King.  White can't prevent the pawn queening.
moves.31. Bf2 c1=Q: Now that 32. Bxd4 is not check, Black has a telling riposte.  Delaying queening would have allowed White to cover the queening square or further harass Black's rook.
